And I also thought it would have been better to have some of the society's full-time staff explore what was available as part of planning the conference. It can be hard to see why some initiatives are worthy of staff time and others are not.

That was one specific example that I thought was a particularly large ask without any guarantee it would be supported by the board. There were other efforts discussed too. I really want to see ISCB put some resources behind the effort that people are already making.

My 2cents: Local childcare is one way, but providing travel grants and accommodation for carers is often preferred. Don’t pay for travel for keynotes (who usually have plenty) and you’ve probably got enough money to cover it.

When @ iscb has people who want to volunteer time to help us live up to our values, we should put resources behind it. Otherwise, conferences and societies that do things better will become the premier venues in our field. And I'm a lifetime member so let's not screw this up.

Still, these folks care enough to jump through these hoops. Please help to make sure their efforts are fruitful. If you're still around # ISMB18/ # ISMB2018 and see a member of the @ ISCB board, let them know that this core value is important: https://www.iscb.org/cms_addon/leadership/index.php …

The next step for these folks is to: 1) Figure out how to offer childcare in Basel, a place that none of them live. 2) Develop a budget by Oct 15 for this and other much-needed efforts. 3) Submit this budget to the @ iscb executive committee. It may then go to the @ iscb board.

ISCB has diversity as a core value. A core value guides you because it's right, even if it costs something. I had the opportunity to meet with some @ iscb leadership at # ISMB2018/ # ISMB18 alongside with folks working on diversity. pic.twitter.com/84i3zOWBX4

Let's talk about # diversity at # ISMB2018/ # ISMB18. Here's something obvious: look around you. We're better than some CS meetings, but we have a ways to go. Here's something less obvious: there are people who have been working on this for years as volunteers.

CHESS is a new human gene database that we built using 9,765 GTEx RNA-seq experiments. It includes many genes and splice variants not found in standard databases. All are supported by expression data, but it's a work in progress. I'll be talking about it at # ISMB2018 on Friday
It'll be nice to catch up with # bioinformatics/ # compbio folks at # ISMB2018 this weekend. See everyone soon!
